original_text:
#Intersting Her name is Nithya Senani Samaranayake. She worked as a flight attendant for #SriLankan Airlines for a while. Namal #Rajapaksa, who wanted to get additional work from her, took the necessary steps to attach her to the Presidential Secretariat. Accordingly, the Secretary to the President, Mr. Lalith Weeratunga, gave her an appointment as Special Project Coordinator in the Office of the President‚Äôs Private Secretary on 23 June 2010. The fixed monthly salary was Rs. 35000.00. In addition, she was paid Rs. 22680.00 as fuel allowance and Rs. 30000.00 as transportation allowance per month. The total amount that Ms. Samaranayake received per month from her new job was Rs. 87680.00.

The Weliamuna Committee, which was appointed to investigate Sri Lankan Airlines, questioned Senani Samaranayake in this regard. The answers given to some of the questions asked were as follows.

She does not know what projects she did from Temple Trees.

She was released from Sri Lankan Airlines to Temple Trees at the request of Mr. Namal Rajapaksa.

She cannot recall the names of others who worked with her at Temple Trees or the Presidential Secretariat. She only remembers Mrs. Deepa Liyanage.

She did not work in the Presidential Secretariat. It was in Temple Trees. However, she could not say exactly where in Temple Trees the office she worked was. She said it was somewhere in Temple Trees.

There was no book to sign to confirm her arrival and departure from the office.

She was provided with a fuel allowance and a transport allowance, but since Namal provided the transport, she spent that money on her personal needs.

Even though she was released from SriLankan Airlines, SriLankan Airlines continued to pay her full salary and 50% of the productivity allowance. Accordingly, her monthly salary from the airline was approximately Rs. 70500.00. Her monthly income from both sides was Rs. 158000.00.

She was also promoted to the rank of flight attendant on 27 March 2014 while she was working full-time at Temple Trees.

She worked at Temple Trees until Mahinda Rajapaksa lost his position on 9 January 2015. Three days later, she returned to her old job.

The total amount paid to her by SriLankan Airlines as salary and allowances during her time at Temple Trees was Rs. 4,133, 622.00. The Sand Anvil Report has stated that this is a violation of Circular No. 33 relating to government-owned companies. Therefore, the committee stating that this is a criminal act has said that an investigation should be conducted in this regard.

Ms. Senanayake's story does not end there. A year after the Sand Anvil Report, she was arrested. And not for the reasons mentioned earlier. She was accused of being involved in laundering Rs. 45 million in black money while acting as a director of two companies owned by Mr. Namal Rajapaksa, N.R. consultation Pvt Ltd and Gowers Corporation Pvt Ltd.

The total amount that Ms. Samaranayake received per month from her new job was Rs. 87680.00.

The Weliamuna Committee, which was appointed to investigate Sri Lankan Airlines, questioned Senani Samaranayake in this regard. The answers given to some of the questions asked were as follows.

She does not know what projects she did from Temple Trees.

She was released from Sri Lankan Airlines to Temple Trees at the request of Mr. Namal Rajapaksa.

Even though she was released from SriLankan Airlines, SriLankan Airlines continued to pay her full salary and 50% of the productivity allowance. Accordingly, her monthly salary from the airline was approximately Rs. 70500.00. Her monthly income from both sides was Rs. 158000.00.

Indian High Commission exhibition on Buddhist heritage at National Museum, Colombo

Free train services between Anuradhapura and Mihintale

Thousands of pilgrims gathering at sacred sites

Represents Cultural Diplomacy (Milton Cummings) - exchange of cultural assets

Demonstrates Public Diplomacy (Nicholas Cull) - engaging foreign publics through culture

üíπ HISTORICAL DIMENSIONS OF INDIA-SRI LANKA BUDDHIST CONNECTION

üöÄ Emperor Ashoka's Buddhist Missions üìàüáÆüá≥üá±üá∞

Third Century BCE Expansion:

Nine Buddhist missions dispatched across known world

Sri Lanka mission led by Arahat Mahinda (Ashoka's son)

Accompanied by Arahants Ittiya, Uttiya, Sambala, Baddasala

Samanera Sumana and Bhanduka Upasaka as supporting missionaries

Reflects Imperial Buddhism (Richard Gombrich) - state-sponsored religious expansion

Aligns with Mauryan Diplomacy (Romila Thapar) - cultural outreach as foreign policy

Doctrinal Foundation:

Introduction of Pali Canon to Sri Lanka

Establishment of monastic order (Sangha)

Construction of first Buddhist temples and stupas

Preservation of original Buddhist teachings

Demonstrates Religious Institutionalization (Max Weber) - formal organization of religious practices

Exemplifies Textual Preservation (Sheldon Pollock) - maintaining sacred literature

Introduction of writing system (Brahmi script)

Development of art and architecture

Establishment of educational institutions

Creation of irrigation systems and urban planning

Reflects Civilizational Transfer (Arnold Toynbee) - comprehensive cultural transmission

Aligns with Cultural Diffusion (Franz Boas) - spread of cultural innovations

Fa-Hien's visit to Sri Lanka (5th century CE)

Buddhaghosa's arrival from India (5th century CE)

Tooth Relic's arrival from Kalinga (4th century CE)

Continuous scholarly exchanges between monasteries

Represents Scholarly Networks (Sheldon Pollock) - intellectual connections across regions

Demonstrates Pilgrimage Circuits (Diana Eck) - sacred geography connecting regions

"NPP government won‚Äôt last long, and Namal Rajapaksa will be President soon."

That‚Äôs the threat made to a key witness by ex-Brigadier Shammi Kumara Ratne, main accused in the ongoing trial over the abduction and murder of journalist Prageeth Eknaligoda.

He‚Äôs now been remanded for witness intimidation, but the message is loud and clear... the old guard still believes it can return to power and erase all consequences.

Still think Namal is a choice for the future?

15 years since Prageeth vanished, his case drags on, and those accused feel emboldened enough to make threats during the trial.

Why?

Because the deeper machinery of state, military, intelligence and bureaucracy is still wired deeply to the Rajapaksas.

They don‚Äôt just want a comeback, they need it... because without it, the full weight of accountability might finally catch up with them.

To those still protecting them, take note... they won‚Äôt be able to save you. Their time is up, their crimes have caught up, and there‚Äôs no redemption coming.

Maybe it‚Äôs time to flip... while you still can.

A Kano State High Court sitting on Miller Road, Kano, has restrained the Nigerian Police Force and the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission, EFCC, from detaining or arresting a Kafanchan-based farmer, Ali Haruna Abbah, over a dispute with his Indian business partner, Sajith Madhu.

The court, presided over by Justice Fatima Adamu, also granted Mr Abbah‚Äôs request to join the Nigerian Police Force, the Inspector General of Police, and the Commissioner of the Police Force Intelligence Department as the fourth to sixth respondents in the suit.

original_text:
President Anura Kumara Dissanayake begins an official visit to Germany at the invitation of President Frank-Walter Steinmeier.

üá±üá∞ü§ùüá©üá™

#SriLanka #LKA #Germany #DiplomacyLK 
He meets key leaders to strengthen ties in trade, investment, digital economy & vocational training. 

President Anura Kumara Disanayaka undertakes an official visit to the Federal Republic of Germany from 11 to 13 June 2025 on the invitation of the President of Germany, Frank-Walter Steinmeier. 
¬†
During this visit President Disanayaka will hold bilateral discussions with the President of Germany, key ministers of the Federal Government and other dignitaries to discuss new avenues for cooperation including in the spheres of trade, digital economy, investment and vocational training opportunities based on the government priorities.
¬†
President Disanayaka will Chair a Business Forum, organized by the German Chamber of Commerce and Industry (DIHK), with key industries in Germany to highlight Sri Lanka‚Äôs economic transformation, investment opportunities available, growth potential of the country and opportunities for building new trade ties between the two countries.¬†
¬†
Further, the President will meet tourism and travel industry associations of Germany during this visit.
¬†
The President will be accompanied by the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Foreign Employment and Tourism Vijitha Herath and Senior Government officials. @anuradisanayake @GermanyinSL

original_text:
Let us unite in building a modern, ethical society rooted in the timeless teachings of the Buddha. At Mihintale, President Anura Kumara Dissanayake emphasized the need to preserve our spiritual heritage and restore Anuradhapura to its former glory.

@anuradisanayake 

President Anura Kumara Disanayake Calls for National Unity Through the Teachings of the Buddha at Poson Festival

MIHINTALE, June 10 ‚Äì President Anura Kumara Disanayake called on the nation to unite in fostering a positive social transformation rooted in Sri Lanka‚Äôs rich cultural heritage and the timeless teachings of the Buddha. Speaking at the National Poson Festival held at the sacred Mihintale temple grounds today, the President emphasized the profound civilizational impact that Buddhism has had on Sri Lankan society.

The annual festival, held under the theme ‚ÄúMay the world be enlightened by the teachings of the Buddha,‚Äù commemorates the historic arrival of Arahant Mahinda Thero, which the President described as a pivotal moment that laid the foundation for a disciplined, spiritually grounded, and culturally refined nation.

‚ÄúHow can we truly celebrate Poson without remembering Mihintale and the deep spiritual significance it holds?‚Äù the President asked, underlining the central role of Mihintale in the nation‚Äôs Buddhist heritage.

He stressed the importance of preserving the spiritual and cultural legacies of sacred sites like Mihintale and ensuring they are passed down to future generations. ‚ÄúThis is not merely a cultural obligation, but a national responsibility,‚Äù he said, adding that only citizens who are spiritually and culturally connected to their heritage are capable of shouldering this task meaningfully.

President Disanayake further announced that the government has launched a comprehensive programme to restore and redevelop the ancient city of Anuradhapura in a manner that reflects its historical grandeur. ‚ÄúAnuradhapura was not only our first city but also the site of the island‚Äôs first reservoir, first surgical operation, and great feats of irrigation like Yodha Ela,‚Äù he noted.

He reiterated that the arrival of Arahant Mahinda ushered in not just religious transformation, but also social, cultural, and political advancement, firmly establishing Sri Lanka as the heartland of Theravada Buddhism.

The President concluded his address by reaffirming the government‚Äôs commitment to rebuilding a modern, ethically guided, and culturally enriched state. ‚ÄúWe must forge a society that upholds new ethical, social, and environmental principles‚Äîguided always by the wisdom of the Buddha,‚Äù he said.

The National Poson Festival drew large crowds from across the country, reflecting the deep reverence and continued relevance of the Buddhist heritage in Sri Lanka‚Äôs national consciousness.

original_text: The Krrish case involves allegations that Namal Rajapaksa misappropriated Rs. 70 million meant for rugby development, with funds transferred via Nimal Perera‚Äôs accounts. Perera is also linked to the Airbus bribery scandal, receiving US$ 800,000 from related bribes. Sri Lanka is pursuing legal action against Airbus for compensation. Both cases are ongoing, with a pre-trial conference for the Krrish case set for June 27, 2025. Rajapaksa and Perera deny wrongdoing, claiming political motives. original_text:
The Sri Lankan Cabinet has suspended Commissioner General of Prisons Thushara Upuldeniya following allegations of the unlawful release of prisoners under the Presidential Pardon granted for Vesak Poya. This decision, made during a Cabinet meeting chaired by President Anura Kumara Dissanayake, aims to allow an impartial investigation.

The Criminal Investigation Department (CID) is probing claims that unapproved inmates, including one from Anuradhapura Prison, were released under the guise of the Vesak amnesty. The prison's Superintendent has already been arrested, and a statement has been recorded from Upuldeniya.

The CID investigation, initiated after a complaint from the Presidential Secretariat, found that several prisoners were released illegally, not just in this instance but also during previous amnesty events. Further inquiries and document reviews are ongoing.

original_text:
Today is Sajith's birthday. I am sharing a priceless picture shot by Vinoo Krishnan just to relive some memories.

Sajith (aka Chief to most of us) was a zen master of minimalism. Exertion was a word that didn't exist in his dictionary. What he did came effortlessly to him. Art, choice of typography, ideas, wit, sarcasm, everything flowed without appearing laboured. He avoided papads because they make a lot of noise. His dress code was a careful collection of grey and black tees. His layouts rarely packed puffery or ornamental frills. Everything was just right in proportions.

As his copy partner for years, it was a delight to observe him and learn from close quarters. He broke his rule of straining too much just once. When he was in 1pointsize, a creative boutique run by Sharad, him, and me, he decided to do the heavy lifting to raise the art standards of Chennai. Singlehandedly, campaign after campaign, he made designers and art directors realise the power of craft, ideas, and minimalism. Every piece was beautiful. Executed with class. Nothing in his book had a morsel of cringe. That was his unique gift.

I've missed his deft, delicate touch for years. I always search for a Sajith in my art partners, knowing fully well that a Sajith is a once-in-a-lifetime experience. They don't make any like him. Sajith would hate to see his clones. What he relished most was discovering new talents and new ways to push the craft.

So the best way to celebrate Sajith is by launching a little award in his name. Hence Blue Noodles is announcing the CPSAJITH AWARD. It is going to be an annual award show for worthy young art directors and designers. We will invite applicants from across India, preferably below 35. There will be only one winner. The winner will be crowned as the DESIGNER OF THE YEAR and will receive a cash prize of Rs 1 Lakh. Details on the award show will be put out soon.

It is our small tribute to the giant who walked amongst us. Happy Birthday, Sajith. Hope you don't disapprove of it. #Sajith #CPSajithAward

I have my skepticisms but not that level of bad üòÖ At least this time, the faces have fully changed. Under Yahapalana, it was still Ranil and Maithripala. History has shown that Ranil and the Rajapaksas are two sides of the same coin. Their policy stance differ, but they represent the same political culture. Even today, Ranil and his NDF have proven no different. And for the country‚Äôs sake, I really hope that‚Äôs not the case this time.

My main concern with this administration is speed. Yes, I know real change takes time - especially with constitutional reform and major overhauls. Some timelines have already been shared for later. But let‚Äôs be honest: people only begin to feel the impact of reform after 5‚Äì10 years.

The only clear and immediate progress so far is in law and order. It‚Äôs not perfect, but undeniably better than previous governments - to deny that would just be blind lol.

That said, the economy is on a ticking clock. Debt repayments resume in 2028. Time is not on our side. This administration has sweeping powers - so they need to act fast. Reforms can‚Äôt wait.

original_text:
President Anura Kumara Dissanayake met with Australian Deputy PM & Defence Minister Richard Marles today to boost üá±üá∞üá¶üá∫ ties.

Australia praised Sri Lanka‚Äôs anti-corruption drive & reaffirmed support for stronger cooperation in trade, security & investment.
@anuradisanayake @RichardMarlesMP @AusHCSriLanka 

President Anura Kumara Disanayake held discussions with the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence of AustraliaRichard Marles at the Presidential Secretariat this morning (03). The meeting focused on further strengthening the historic ties between Sri Lanka and Australia, with a particular emphasis on enhancing bilateral cooperation.
President Disanayake highlighted Sri Lanka‚Äôs progress towards economic stability and briefed Deputy Prime Minister Marles on the government‚Äôs ongoing efforts to combat corruption and fraud. He also expressed appreciation for the Australian Government‚Äôs support in recent maritime security operations and its assistance in addressing illegal trade, human trafficking, terrorism and arms smuggling. The President further reaffirmed that Sri Lanka remains a secure destination for tourism and investment.
Deputy Prime Minister Marles, reflecting on the 70-year economic and political relationship between the two countries, conveyed Australia‚Äôs commitment to working closely with Sri Lanka‚Äôs new administration. He praised the government‚Äôs anti-corruption initiatives and emphasized that enhancing trade, economic, political, tourism and investment relations was a central objective of his visit.
The Australian delegation included Mr Paul Stephens, Australian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka; Mr Gregory Laurence Moriarty, Secretary of the Department of Defence; Mr Simon Eric O'Connor, Senior Adviser to the Deputy Prime Minister; and MsLalita Kapur, Australian Deputy High Commissioner to Sri Lanka. Representing Sri Lanka were Dr Nandika Sanath Kumanayake, Secretary to the President and Mr Roshan Gamage, Additional Secretary to the President.

In January, Xi met with Sri Lankan President Anura Kumara Dissanayake in Beijing, where he reaffirmed China‚Äôs support for Sri Lanka‚Äôs economic development and the deepening of cooperation in key areas such as high-quality Belt and Road projects, modern agriculture, the digital and marine economies.

original_text:
President Anura Kumara Dissanayake announced that Mahinda Siriwardena, the current Secretary to the Ministry of Finance, will retire at the end of this month. Following his retirement, he will become the Alternate Executive Director at the Asian Development Bank (ADB), representing Sri Lanka and six other countries.

The announcement was made during the inauguration of National Tax Week. President Dissanayake praised Siriwardena's role in leading key tax reforms aimed at transforming Sri Lanka from one of the lowest tax-collecting countries into a more efficient and fair system. The President expressed deep gratitude for Siriwardena‚Äôs service and leadership in driving these reforms.
